title: Monday, 8th July 2019

11:09 am

Okay, so is this Christian Sewing finally setting out the masterplan to land this thing safely, or is it scrambling for a parachute as the ground rushes towards him?

Focusing on Asset Management seems like a wise play, given demographics in the EU, and trend towards low-cost options away from alternatives. But not a high-return play, as you say BE.

Mouselet looking for a high-return franchise at this point in the cycle seems like an excellent way of ending up as the next PPI
IMP.GLD and less landesbank
Excel Developer @BE: Ah funding costs, what is Deutsche Bank's spread over LIBOR? Anyone have a credit default swap price?
Bluesky21 @JP I am not sure asset management would work well for them
BE11:20am

And the lack of capital hike in the restructuring is a notable thing here. Wonder if they considered bundling one in?

Bluesky21 Where IBs have made asset management work, it's usually in combination with a wealth management business
BE11:20am

Let me get some Kepler.

Bluesky21 (MS, JPM, the Swiss banks clearly)
red yes i am not so sure there is a purpose for db apart from serving german retail. and if thats not profitable...
11:21 am
BE11:21am

In our view, the CRU unit, and its ability to deleverage without incurring too important losses is the key to DBK’s restructuring plan without a capital increase. By 2021, DBK expects to have reduced CRU’s RWA by EUR28bn, which corresponds to 120bps of CET1 ratio. However, the key question is how much the wind down or disposal of the CRU unit cost will be. We believe that DBK can withstand EUR3bn of losses from the CRU unit. Above that level, further deleveraging and or profit generation from other business unit would be needed. We currently value DBK with a SOP and a COE of 12.3%.

Bluesky21 Standalone asset management will be like SLA (Aberdeen)
Mouselet managing to do asset management for a mass market better than Vanguard/Blackrock sounds like a challenging request
BE11:22am

Okay, so let's spin to the numbers .....

BE11:23am

Bluesky21 @Mouselet Good point. Intesa is the only example I can think of
red only way i see is an european alliance play with a french big'un
11:23 am
BE11:23am

So assuming the CRU unit can be run down without a single execution error and effectively for free, DB should be fine.

Bluesky21 Selling investment products (including "insurance") to Italian savers who can't get any yield at home
BE11:24am

Back to Kepler.

Excel Developer @Mouselet: they'd have to specialise in "below-Dax" ETFs and other German stock sgements which iShares don't bother with.
BE11:24am

[E]very billion of RWA to run down could cost EUR0.2bn. If this was the case, it would represent a huge cost for DBK (c.EUR15bn). However, we believe that those assets will not incur important losses as, according to DBK, those assets are low-return assets or assets that no longer fit the new strategy, hence not toxic assets.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

If we take a pro-forma CET1 ratio, assuming EUR4.5bn of restructuring costs directly impacting the CET1 capital and EUR28bn of CRU RWA deleveraging, we end up with a CET1 ratio of 13.5%. This corresponds to EUR3bn of capital buffer before reaching 12.5%.

BE11:24am

Hence, DBK could absorb, in our view, EUR3bn of CRU losses. This does not take into account any operational risk RWA deleveraging or any profit stemming from the other operating divisions that could mitigate the effect of the CRU losses on DBK’s capital.

#REF! I've always wondered about 'bad bank' assets. Who works there to adminster it. Pay can't be great and job has ticking time bomb element. Can't motivate good performance.. does it make bad assets worse?
JP11:26am

And here's UBS:

11:26 am
JP11:26am

The attempt to break out of the self-feeding debt/equity circle
As expected, DB announced strategic changes that are probably even more radical than suggested by market expectations and press articles. The new plan shows the willingness and determination to change the profile of DB. We think the measures are probably even more radical on the cost side than on the RWA/LRD shrinkage front. Ultimately, the new strategy in our view aims at breaking through the self-feeding debt/equity circle which we have often discussed in our research and to make Deutsche less of a levered market play vulnerable to external events. Can DB become a German version of BNP with a more balanced, less IB-skewed profile? BNP after all has a 200bp lower regulatory CET 1 capital requirement. For details of the plan see the note.

JP11:26am

8% ROTE in 2022 – a material improvement but also highlighting the profile
Cutting costs by one quarter while growing revenues by 10% over four years in the current market environment and while undergoing massive restructuring could be seen as challenging by some. DB plans to do the restructuring without a capital increase.
A potential doubler for the optimistic and patient investor
EUR25bn revenues and EUR17bn costs could translate into a net profit of EUR4.4bn (8% ROTE) and an EPS of EUR2.- (PE 2022 3.5x). The fair value per share could be EUR14.7 (11% COE, 1% growth, discounted back two years). The fair value assuming flat revenues until 2022 and unchanged costs could translate into a fair value of EUR9.2. At the current share price level, the market seems to assume a revenue decrease of 5% until 2022 (and cost targets achieved). Changes to TNAV could change the fair value per share.

Bluesky21 Per Jonn Cryan's gaffe a few years a back, there really isn't much point to Deutsche Bank beyond transaction banking
JP11:27am

Valuation: PT and recommendation are under review
We think the short-term market reaction could be positive as mentioned previously. Progress over the coming quarters could then further increase the market confidence in the plan. That said, overall market conditions and restructuring uncertainties could materially impact revenues. Some key questions remain: What about frictions and (negative) side-effects? Execution uncertainties? RWA inflation and other regulatory uncertainties? What about margins and competitive dynamics? More details tomorrow at 2pm CET and at a Q4 inv day.

red @#REF!its an illusion

Watch out for the second order effects: DBK’s plan involves running off assets that accounted for €2.5bn of revenue in 2018 [10% of group total].

However, we are concerned that this reduction could impair the franchise further, leading to additional revenue attrition.

11:33 am

8% ROTE in 2022 looks difficult to achieve: DBK now targets an 8% ROTE in 2022 but this relies on it growing core revenues by over 2% per annum (keeping group revenues broadly flat) while reducing adjusted costs by €6bn to €17bn. Considering the adjustments it is making and the potential second order effects of this, we struggle to see how it will deliver on this target.

Is that enough DB?

The UK Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) has intends to fine British Airways £183.4m (1.5% of global turnover in 2017) in relation to the previously-disclosed theft of customer data in 2018. IAG has expressed its surprise and disappointment at the size of the proposed fine, and indicated its intention to appeal. The fine equates to c.9p per IAG share. While IAG has more than adequate liquidity to cover the fine (Dec 2018 cash €3.8bn, total liquidity €6.3bn), the penalty is still substantial.

BE11:42am

There. The precedent of a £183m fine because of a Magecart hack is probably more interesting and the ones exposed to that are ........ well, every single company in the world .......

undefined
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Speaking of .....

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 2,541, down 66 (-2.53%), High: 2,624, Low: 2,535, Volume: 181.96k
BE11:43am

Sunday Times story reporting 100 redundancies at its HQ, mainly on the marketing side.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Which gives the likes of Stifel an opportunity to say sell.

BE11:44am

Another sign of weakness from ASOS. An article in The Times yesterday reported a
round of job cuts at ASOS, quoting a botched warehouse opening in America and slowing
sales as the main reasons. We, on the other hand, think that the company is struggling to
recover the lost market share in this current retail environment, without a distinctive own
label and strong social media marketing.
Traditional marketing under pressure? The online fast-fashion retailer is consulting on
about 100 redundancies at its head office in London. Most of the roles under threat are in
the marketing department (marketing expenses are c.4% of ASOS revenues), according
to unconfirmed reports. The news comes at a time when marketing efforts on social media
have been quite noticeable, hence we believe the cuts might be focused on traditional
marketing channel positions.
Valuation. In our recent note, we underlined that the stock had re-rated despite the
profit warning (it currently trades at 47x 2019 Cal. P/E, a 17% premium to boohoo). Our
estimates are slightly below consensus for FY19 (3% below FY19 consensus PBT), as
the company has set clear expectations for the year - sales growth +15%, EBIT margin
2%), but 12% below FY20 consensus PBT, as we see ASOS struggling to improve sales
growth and profitability at the same time. Next reporting date: trade update due on July 23.

#REF! if sellside comment on fine's for data breaches, then their employer has one. could be awkward...
JP11:45am

I find ASOS kind of weird, 50 per cent gross margins seems really high for a low volume business.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

With, as we've said a lot, a very low barrier to entry and a thousand very similar competitors.

marktime I need to understand the precise reasons why IAG might be fined so heavily, it implies fault and negligence
JP11:46am

Here's Neil Campling at Mirabaud:

red think IT costs are going to go a lot higher for these online businesses.
JP11:46am

The Sunday Times reported that Asos is consulting on about 100 redundancies at its head office in London. Most of the roles under threat are said to be in the marketing department (marketing expenses are c.4% of ASOS revenues). We think the cuts would most likely be focused on traditional marketing channels while the company pivots to making significant efforts on social media. So rebalancing in this way would be a positive step long term.

Omikin On BA. As someone who flies with them every week and not by choice, it's remarkable how bad their IT remains at the front end. On the basis that they clearly still cannot tie up what are obvioulsly various legacy systems (loyalty bits don't connect with bookings which don't always connect with check in) they are uninvestable. Oh and 50% of the staff look like they'd rather be somewhere else.
11:46 am
JP11:47am

Asos is certainly in a transition period; investing for growth, making changes to own label products, multiple changes to the website, revamped social media strategy, and customer interaction initiatives. Stabilising sales growth, potential recovery in Europe and strong growth in the U.S. could all act as positive catalysts against low expectations. Solid top-line growth could be underpinned by improving customer acquisition. However, some argue that the risk is this comes at a higher cost of acquisition with higher promotions are still being used as a recruitment tool. Even if this was the case if a digital business can see accelerating top-line growth this would be the most important dynamic – then you could slow the tap of promotions and drive incremental profitability thereafter. While aware that we may not see a significant improvement in the P3 trading statement (due 23rd July) we do think risk/reward is more favourable in the second half of 2019 with expectations low, time for new strategies to bed in, and the valuation discount to Zalando now looking extreme.

BE11:47am

Hm ......... I believe ASOS used to do the full monty with its summer parties. Big venue, bands, free bars open all night, etc ....

BE11:47am

This year they went to a pub.

Omg smileOmg smileOmg smile

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 2,003, up 42.2 (+2.15%), High: 2,024, Low: 1,983, Volume: 753.04k

Kiwi-juice Maxcyte if time allows? If anything was published recently. 30% drop on no news thx

Bluesky21 £200m buyback is 1% of market cap
Bluesky21 Although it's almost roughly two thirds of the disposal proceeds in FY18

The idea here is that the divi was always assumed to be toast

So the fact that it's (probably) getting paid in 2019 is good, relatively. And the £200m is fine as a precedent, assuming you believe the shares are undervalued, which if you hold them you probably do.

Kiwi-juice IMPs divi cut too small sadly. The issue will come back again next year
Bluesky21 Free cash flow, if you adjust out the one-offs, was flat in FY16-18; so the dividend rising 10% p.a. was the direct cause of the slowdown in deleveraging
11:52 am
BE11:53am

Here's Caz.

BE11:53am

While IMB
confirms 2019 dividend growth of 10% and announces a SBB of up to £200m before the end of CY19, it guides
for a progressive dividend policy (“growing annually from the current level”, “taking into account underlying
business performance”’, targeting 2-2.5x ND/EBITDA) dropping its commitment to grow DPS by 10%. We
see the following as positive: 1) the company view on total shareholder return to encompass share
buybacks, especially attractive at current share price level, 2) the acknowledgement that its dividend policy
was unsustainable (as we have flagged previously), 3) the increased flexibility around FCF usage. A £200m
SBB should lead to c1% EPS accretion on an annualized basis, but should also be supportive of the share price.
However we remain concerned about the potential need for organic, or M&A led, investments following
disappointing NGP growth in H119 and increased competition in alternative nicotine’s products. Given
the lack of visibility on these issues, we remain Neutral but we see upside to the share price in the short
term supported by today’s announcement. We favor BATS (OW) to IMB (N). IMB shares have been under
pressure, down -18% YTD, and currently trade at 6.4x PE20E (vs Tobacco peers 11.5x), EV/EBITDA20E of
6.6x (vs Tobacco peers 10x), and with a 2020E dividend yield of 12% (vs Tobacco peers 7%), assuming 10%
dividend growth in 2020E.

Bluesky21 A lot depends on whether the premium cigar business would fetch the £1.5bn that "a source close to the company" told the FT it would get
BE11:53am

And RBC.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

We are not surprised at the abandonment of the 10% dividend growth target; indeed, in our view, it should have happened a while ago. But nor do we think this statement changes much. Our view of Imperial Brands’ prospects – at least as the latter are encapsulated in this morning’s statement – are considerably less sanguine that management’s.

If one had no preconceptions about Imperial Brands’ financial position, this morning’s announcement of its new capital allocation policy would make sense. But we do and it doesn’t, in our opinion. The starting point is that we forecast Imperial Brands to have net debt/EBITDA (after restructuring) of 3.0x by September 2019. True, we forecast that to reduce by 0.1 turns per annum, but even without the investment in ‘targeted M&A opportunities’ foreseen by Imperial Brands this looks precarious, based as it is on profitability from an industry undergoing significant disruption in the form of next generation products (NGPs). Bear in mind, too, that the £2bn disposal programme will presumably involve a reduction in EBITDA, so not have a huge effect on Imperial Brands’ net debt/EBTIDA ratio.

Bluesky21 Because otherwise it's a pretty large gap between net debt / EBITDA at 2.9x at FY18 and the 2.0-2.5x they want for investment grade
BE11:54am

Slightly surprised that, with Imperial at 6.4x 2020 in a market that's changed quite rapidly over the past couple of years, we've not heard many retreads of the consolidation stuff.

marktime I suspect smoking now kills fewer people than poor metropolitan air quality
Bluesky21 Consolidation would need to involve multiple parties
undefined
11:55 am
JP11:55am

Yeah, it's not hard to imagine some M&A soon.

red JT for IMB. probably

BE11:57am

ValueAct's arguments that short term focus on trading resulted in Merlin being undervalued are equally pertinent for Cineworld in our view. The company generates $500m of FCF post all interest and capex annually (market cap value $4.5bn) and could easily support c6x debt in a PE vehicle if we estimate a 20% IRR at a 400p takeover. The falling share price caused by the film release schedule that is driving short term earnings weakness suggests the stock would be a better vehicle for investors with a longer term time horizon. In addition to strong returns, PE would benefit from the long term potential for Regal from a management team that trebled the Cineworld share price after taking control in 2014. We believe the weak film slate in H1 offers a fantastic buying opportunity for investors and PE alike and retain our Top Pick rating and 400p PT.
